class=\"widget widget-ArticleTopInfo widget-instance-OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    Serendipitous discovery of a strong-lensed galaxy in integral field spectroscopy from MUSE\r\n<i class='' title='' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Llu\u00eds Galbany</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Llu\u00eds Galbany\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-default\"><!----></a></span>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n Clinical Library - University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nHope Fox Eccles Clinical Library - University of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f479%2f1%2f262%2f5032805\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446090 id=\"118446090\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 is a bright red elliptical galaxy at redshift 0.0661 that presents two extended sources at 2\u2033 to the north-east and 1\u2033 to the south-west. The sizes and surface brightnesses of the two blue sources are consistent with a gravitationally-lensed background galaxy. In this paper, we present Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) observations of this galaxy from the All-weather MUse Supernova Integral-field Nearby Galaxies (AMUSING) survey, and report the discovery of a background lensed galaxy at redshift 0.1915, together with other 15 background galaxies at redshifts ranging from 0.09 to 0.9, that are not multiply imaged. We have extracted aperture spectra of the lens and all the sources and fit the stellar continuum with STARLIGHT to estimate their stellar and emission line properties. A trace of past merger and active nucleus activity is found in the lensing galaxy, while the background lensed galaxy is found to be star-forming. Modelling the lensing potential with a singular isothermal ellipsoid, we find an Einstein radius of 1<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>04, which corresponds to 1.9\u00a0kpc at the redshift of the lens and it is much smaller than its effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09\u2033). Comparing the Einstein mass and the STARLIGHT stellar mass within the same aperture yields a dark matter fraction of 18 per\u2009cent\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08 \u2009per\u2009cent within the Einstein radius. The advent of large surveys such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) will discover a number of strong-lensed systems, and here we demonstrate how wide-field integral field spectroscopy offers an excellent approach to study them and to precisely model lensing effects.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: spectroscopic&quot;\">techniques: spectroscopic</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: general&quot;\">galaxies: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446092 id=\"118446092\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">General relativity predicts that light from distant galaxies is deflected by foreground massive objects, such as more nearby galaxies or clusters. In cases where the source and deflector are sufficiently well aligned, multiple images of the source will form around the lensing foreground object (Einstein <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1915</a>; Zwicky <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1937</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing produces highly magnified images that allow the study of fainter and smaller galaxies than would otherwise be possible with current instrumentation (Narayan &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). Also, it provides the most precise and accurate method to determine the masses of galaxies in a model-free fashion being independent of assumptions such as the initial mass function (IMF) or galaxy dynamics (Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In addition, the comparison between the inferred total mass distribution in strong lenses to their observed brightness profile provides valuable information about the galaxy dark matter content and distribution (Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Strong lensing systems can also place constraints on cosmological parameters (Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Low redshift lenses are particularly interesting systems as their Einstein radii form at a much smaller physical scale than for higher redshift lenses. This enables studies of the central matter distribution in these lenses. Their much lower distances also allow more detailed follow-up of the lens kinematics and stellar populations. Recent studies have combined these approaches to place tight constraints on the IMF (Smith, Lucey &amp; Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the validity of General relativity (Collett 2018a), and the Hubble constant (Collett et al 2018b, in prep). Unfortunately, despite the utility of low redshift strong lenses only a handful are known (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) due to the rarity of massive galaxies and the small volume at very low redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While some lensed systems have been discovered serendipitously by visually checking images of the lens, there have been several dedicated attempts to identify strong gravitational lensed objects around massive galaxies. Previous search strategies typically used both photometric or spectroscopic methods. Photometric methods include searching for arc morphologies (e.g. Blakeslee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), or outliers in colour diagrams (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), given that foreground and background objects have different colours. The majority of these methods are based on a priori knowledge of galaxy properties, and visual inspection is usually required. Most recently, new automatic methods based on deep learning are flowering (Lanusse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Alternatively, spectroscopic methods that are based on detecting rogue emission (or absorption) lines in galaxy spectra (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) have been employed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) reported the discovery of a lensed galaxy in integral field spectroscopy (IFS) observations of SDSS J170124.01+372258.0 from the MaNGA survey (Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).This methodology has been greatly extended by Talbot et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) to discover 38 lenses from MaNGA, with lens redshifts spanning 0.02 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>l</em></sub> &lt; 0.13. Despite the clear detection of weak emission lines in the datacube corresponding to a star-forming background galaxy at different redshift than the lens, the low spatial resolution of MaNGA data does not yet allow for a detailed understanding of the observed lensing mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We here report the discovery of strong gravitational lensing by the galaxy 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> in IFS obtained with the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), an IFU instrument with high resolutions in both spectral (<em>R</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03000) and spatial (0.2\u2033/spaxel) dimensions, which permits a detailed reconstruction of the source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the observations. Then, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we describe the lens model and the residual datacube after subtraction. In Section<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, the lensed source. In Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we present a simple model of the observed image configuration and the lensing mass. In Section<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>, we summarize and list our conclusions. Throughout this work, we use the best-fit cosmological parameters of Planck Collaboration et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446100 id=\"118446100\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 is a bright red elliptical galaxy at R.A.\u00a0=\u00a004<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>26, Dec\u00a0=\u00a0\u221202\u00b039\u203227<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>64 with a radial velocity <em>cz</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a019,952\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), corresponding to an angular scale of 1.256\u00a0kpc arcsec<sup>\u22121</sup>. The type Ia supernova LSQ13cwp exploded 9.6\u2033N and 6.1\u2033E from the galaxy core and was discovered on November 8th 2013 (Walker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For this reason, 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 was included in the sample of supernova host galaxies of the All-weather MUse Supernova Integral-field Nearby Galaxies (AMUSING; Galbany et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) survey. AMUSING is an ongoing project aimed at studying the environments of supernovae (SNe) by means of the analysis of a large number of nearby SN host galaxies (redshifts typically between 0.005 and 0.1). The AMUSING sample currently comprises more than 300 galaxies observed in the last six semesters (P95\u2013P100). It also comprises a wide variety of galaxy types with the common characteristics of having hosted a known SN.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 was observed using the integral-field spectrograph MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) at the ESO Very Large Telescope (VLT) UT4 of the Cerro Paranal Observatory during a clear night on 2016 November 7. In the Wide-Field Mode, MUSE covers a continuous sky region of 1\u2032\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u2032 with a small spaxel size of 0.2\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.2\u2033, which limits the spatial resolution of the data to the atmospheric seeing during the observation (\u223c0.7\u2033). MUSE observations cover the wavelength range spanning from 4750\u2009\u00c5\u00a0to 9300\u2009\u00c5, with a spectral sampling of 1.25\u2009\u00c5 and a resolving power <em>R</em> increasing from 1800 in the blue edge to 3600 in the red edge of the spectrum. With its excellent total throughput, MUSE offers an unprecedented combination of sensitivity, spatial resolution, and field of view (FoV).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained four dithered (by a few arcsec) exposures of 700s integration each, totaling 2800s on source, that resulted in a combined datacube with more than 105,000 individual spectra. There are no stars in the field of our MUSE observations, but we checked the image quality of the slow-guiding system (SGS) that uses metrology fields around the MUSE field of view (FoV) to provide a secondary telescope guiding. Three stars were detected in those fields with an average full-width half-maximum (FWHM) of 0.676\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.040 arcsec. We therefore assume throughtout the paper the point spread function (PSF) is a circular Gaussian with an FWHM of 0.7\u2033, which corresponds to a physical resolution of 880\u00a0pc at the redshift of the lens, and it is consistent with the reported Differential imaging motion motor (DIMM) seeing. Data reduction was performed following prescriptions reported in Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) and Kr\u00fchler et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and the reader is referred to those papers for details.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">IFS can be thought as a sequence of two-dimensional (2D) very narrow-band imaging of the Field of view (FoV) covered by the instrument. In the case of MUSE, this translates into 1.25\u2009\u00c5-wide 3,681 images. Each of these images correspond to a different rest-frame wavelength for objects at different redshifts in the FoV.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection of the 2MASX J04035024-0239275 datacube revealed a bright detached source located a few spaxels South-West of the core of the main galaxy. A spectrum extracted with a small aperture at the position of the source resembled that of a typical star-forming galaxy at a higher redshift than the main galaxy (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u223c\u00a00.19). Examining the wavelength slice (narrow-band image) of the datacube corresponding to the H\u03b1 emission of this source (7820\u2009\u00c5), we discovered another source at the North-Eastern side of the 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 core (see inset of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The spectrum of this 2nd source was found to be very similar to the S-E object, and the estimated redshifts were consistent. Further inspection of the datacube revealed up to 15 other galaxies present in the FoV. Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows a synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image from the datacube centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5 in the observer frame,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> where all objects detected are marked with circles of different colours grouped by their corresponding measured redshifts. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists coordinates and spectroscopic redshifts of all objects detected in the FoV. The inner panel presents a zoom-in of the 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 core, from a synthetic narrow-band image centred at 7820\u2009\u00c5, where it can be clearly seen the core (labeled as <em>A</em> throughout the paper) and the two S-W (labeled as <em>B</em>) and N-E (labeled as <em>C</em>) bright blobs.</p>                        <a id=\"118446106\" scrollto-destination=\"118446106\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=fyfthPRzVrM5PqhdM~Pe57Ojn6UsMrGApKAfuiVNY7FlVS0HX4sr~Qi0ARuI9LAH-a4PFElYYS51DEZIJI~CyQ7Vrf8Pjf-lTaxtgtuI64ZgPH8aLJcikXn2N7eCVsHsS-wjLwVSVkeaPWIldesSAUGBMY115qjRSoypmmTuvnqUpmAPcDh6VrYLUIa34ot1zl4kR~8Ybj1c2gF6W5k6a6guNJgRGXsyoZZ29fr19HhR9ahFrrpK59QJTKBKO1ANv8HuzZBxcMnWkv0uHJk-DipBLFUpPYfeN6oTceAOHpJBqRS1tqf8KVCk6vCesfDQBOgI8ieOS0epeI~nlHDiJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. We identified 16 different sources in the field of view, indicated with circles. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source ($z$\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. Supernova LSQ13cwp position is represented by a white plus sign.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446106/sty1448fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446106\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=PlSgyp1SI9sSHdrzwI9iDd5Zh6PzkjPTX8RZ5W5-5CSSyTCkZI4fc065ja5qzvyDNIszwZLHGjPj6nAWRTUs0mhX2mHDuMhdTuRYv0LLl3ZhptVevrF6il4yjOJKQPPYgP8iE7nMLFzxdDhnu70efkwaa-0DZSoSRenj2502jIF~K6jAEzun69Tk5HjUAVvKowL1W4LWlJw4BtlheADTGYXEr6Wyu1boD5kuVKVijQm6qjFy4bWLWXE3LKq9Ql0rV3ZKqMLuZ0JaryGqfYb3bYIFZ7KRyhOXDHgeY1AX1IY2Qw~TO3IvMlA2clCo4QNC9XFEg-In1~p9llkf5uyeMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446106&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. We identified 16 different sources in the field of view, indicated with circles. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. Supernova LSQ13cwp position is represented by a white plus sign.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=fyfthPRzVrM5PqhdM~Pe57Ojn6UsMrGApKAfuiVNY7FlVS0HX4sr~Qi0ARuI9LAH-a4PFElYYS51DEZIJI~CyQ7Vrf8Pjf-lTaxtgtuI64ZgPH8aLJcikXn2N7eCVsHsS-wjLwVSVkeaPWIldesSAUGBMY115qjRSoypmmTuvnqUpmAPcDh6VrYLUIa34ot1zl4kR~8Ybj1c2gF6W5k6a6guNJgRGXsyoZZ29fr19HhR9ahFrrpK59QJTKBKO1ANv8HuzZBxcMnWkv0uHJk-DipBLFUpPYfeN6oTceAOHpJBqRS1tqf8KVCk6vCesfDQBOgI8ieOS0epeI~nlHDiJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source ($z$\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4556\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>E\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>53\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203242<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>0\u00a0</td><td>0.4551\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>F\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>71\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203239<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6\u00a0</td><td>0.4538\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4564\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>48<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4542\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>I\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>8\u00a0</td><td>0.4549\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6\u00a0</td><td>0.0946\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>L\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>8\u00a0</td><td>0.0946\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>M\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>52<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm (merger)\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>67\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203230<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>0\u00a0</td><td>0.0661\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Label<span aria-hidden=\"true\" no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6\u00a0</td><td>0.5937\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>P\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>51\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203248<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>4\u00a0</td><td>0.6286\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Q\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>51<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm (merger)\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>67\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203230<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>0\u00a0</td><td>0.0661\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118446107\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The geometrical configuration of <em>B</em> and <em>C</em> together with their similar spectra, suggested that they may be, in fact, the same object lensed by 2MASX J04035024-0239275. In the rest of the paper, we present an analysis of the lens <em>A</em> and the galaxy <em>B</em> + <em>C</em>, and demonstrate that this is actually the case.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446109 id=\"118446109\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 THE LENS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118446110 id=\"118446110\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Reconstructing the lens</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the images of the background galaxy are clearly seen in the observed cube, their visibility might be enhanced by subtracting a model of the contribution of the foreground galaxy acting as a gravitational lens. We have explored a number of approaches to model the spectrophotometric properties of the lens, namely: isophotal fitting, analytical S\u00e9rsic fitting, and single stellar population (SSP) synthesis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The main differences between these methods is the way they handle the stellar continua and the ionized gas emission. While isophotal and S\u00e9rsic fitting may contain traces of emission lines from the lens because gas and stars are treated together (at each wavelength slice), the SSP fitting model only contain the stellar component. This contamination from the ionized gas is more important close to the lens core, and irrelevant at larger radii. On the other hand, the intensity of the stellar continuum of the lens becomes fainter with radial distance, and SSP fitting does not provide reliable fits. However, isophotal and S\u00e9rsic fitting is noiseless and respects the shape of the lens stellar continuum. Therefore, we use the <em>analytical S\u00e9rsic fit</em> approach to remove the lens contribution from the spectra of all background galaxies (objects <em>D\u2013R</em>; See Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>), and the SSP fitting approach to model the lens and the lensed system in the central region.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Ignoring the signal of all background sources, including the lensed source, we analyzed the lens following the procedures of Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). After correcting all spectra in the datacube for Galactic extinction (<em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>) = 0.134 mag) using dust maps from Schlafly &amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and assuming a Cardelli, Clayton &amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) extinction law with <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1, we fit all spectra in the observed datacube with STARLIGHT (Cid Fernandes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) fixing the redshift at 0.0661, corresponding to the recession velocity of the lens. STARLIGHT estimates the fractional contribution of different SSPs with different ages and metallicities to the stellar continuum in the spectra, assuming that the star formation history of a galaxy can be approximated as the sum of discrete star formation bursts. The fitting makes use of the \u2018Granada-Miles\u2019 (GM) base, which is a combination of the MILES SSP spectra provided by Vazdekis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, as updated by Falc\u00f3n-Barroso et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) for populations older than <em>t</em>\u00a0=\u00a063\u00a0Myr and the Gonz\u00e1lez Delgado et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) models for younger ages. They are based on the Salpeter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1955</a>) Initial Mass Function and the evolutionary tracks of Girardi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), except for the youngest ages (&lt;3\u00a0Myr), which are based on Geneva tracks (Schaller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Charbonnel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Schaerer et\u00a0al. 1993a,b). The GM base is defined as a regular (t, Z) grid of 248 models with 62 ages spanning t\u00a0=\u00a00.001\u201314\u00a0Gyr and four metallicities (Z/Z<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.2, 0.4, 1, and 1.5).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the relatively faint stellar and ionized emission of all background galaxies with respect to the lens, emission lines from background galaxies do not introduce significant contamination in the SSP fitting of the lens. All individual STARLIGHT best fits are then put together in a 3D datacube that describes a model of the lens galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118446115 id=\"118446115\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Separating the background source from the lens</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to separately study the lens and the background source, we removed the contribution of the lens from the source by subtracting the SSP fitting datacube from the 3D observation. The residual contains the ionized emission lines from the lens (consistent with a redshift 0.0661) on top of both the stellar and the gas-phase emission of the source (at redshift 0.1915). We fit all strong emission lines of ionized gas from the lens and the background source (H\u00a0\u03b2, [O\u2009iii] \u03bb5007, [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6548, H\u00a0\u03b1, [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6583) using <span class=\"small-caps\">Pipe3D</span> (S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the lens, the [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6583 emission is stronger than H\u00a0\u03b1 suggesting that the underlying ionization is caused by an AGN. In Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (left panel) we show the [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb6583 2D emission line map of the lens, where the two blobs from the background galaxy are not present. The AGN origin is confirmed by the location of the emission line ratios in the AGN region on the Baldwin, Phillips, Terlevich (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">BPT</a>) diagram shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446118\" scrollto-destination=\"118446118\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=2R6yTn59Z6QZLmlngrHrZ2fywXLp6kHViwj1RxNE7sVBMtLK5VR6nUPXTqgEKb3JJ6C6ROboivisi3QJ32Rdk9eeh5SDK6dwRUIeFiUs1CGIRLJ-L3ODPzQGlRKKokyb-2Avv45w-0dadi6PwRzEP~7FzcPl4Hglq~EO1M9gYQgIpEVB5svhZYfygnc05mSteFQbWITqdYNab7tBabQxa6St-qliHl1X25Ryme~W-nN74rzHKsDS32o80DaX3KmIiJvLUKqjmKvOcqKTWbeXKRSa1Ssldz~BsUWylUzXysOSaR9vnEncAR6XVGEtszI1A5JN2N55HUIqduAXQDp2AQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"22\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a022\u2033cutouts centred at the core of the foreground galaxy acting as a lens. S region indicates the merger region (see Section\u00a03.3). In the left-hand panel, a [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6583 emission line flux map of the lens galaxy (7019\u2009\u00c5 observer-frame), and in the centre and right-hand panels, H\u00a0\u03b1 flux and velocity maps of the background source galaxy (7820\u2009\u00c5 observer-frame). An arc, forming a partial Einstein ring can clearly be identified in central and right-hand panels.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446118/sty1448fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446118\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=ljRjX8WymgiqlNOKQyM3xeBC8bJtehS14d2nSAkh40KXsTQED~SPO1DTriR9pzLMSgtdN4zswWKj0abwrgn9hXkEtvQRK5h2sdqD70XSn5FqT3270KKJ7gZUbI7J4qgrUEXW9cFDNKy7yjoPIGwVG4I3nbufgZzqjgZEIAdArwKVfl2cEsNYZnP~Y5Xx-pTyHpBL-SJenjrMTGJo7HzOXMtKwEBeScjWgw20E878XAz9QQGMsivMvDaTjsBgJ-i98qI3Xn2y~8L8n66ZvwkU9WdOIauvf5pZGwnAYFndC98RQdH-GXh0UUfQHgYprNhxhcHUQ1lOUmh4S6Szs6KQ0g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446118&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">22\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a022\u2033cutouts centred at the core of the foreground galaxy acting as a lens. <em>S</em> region indicates the merger region (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>). In the left-hand panel, a [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb6583 emission line flux map of the lens galaxy (7019\u2009\u00c5 observer-frame), and in the centre and right-hand panels, H\u00a0\u03b1 flux and velocity maps of the background source galaxy (7820\u2009\u00c5 observer-frame). An arc, forming a partial Einstein ring can clearly be identified in central and right-hand panels.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=2R6yTn59Z6QZLmlngrHrZ2fywXLp6kHViwj1RxNE7sVBMtLK5VR6nUPXTqgEKb3JJ6C6ROboivisi3QJ32Rdk9eeh5SDK6dwRUIeFiUs1CGIRLJ-L3ODPzQGlRKKokyb-2Avv45w-0dadi6PwRzEP~7FzcPl4Hglq~EO1M9gYQgIpEVB5svhZYfygnc05mSteFQbWITqdYNab7tBabQxa6St-qliHl1X25Ryme~W-nN74rzHKsDS32o80DaX3KmIiJvLUKqjmKvOcqKTWbeXKRSa1Ssldz~BsUWylUzXysOSaR9vnEncAR6XVGEtszI1A5JN2N55HUIqduAXQDp2AQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"22\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a022\u2033cutouts centred at the core of the foreground galaxy acting as a lens. An arc, forming a partial Einstein ring can clearly be identified in central and right-hand panels.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118446119\" scrollto-destination=\"118446119\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=FmHO9Jpb~BQLQ0i67FeZph1nFsVXDoFGATj900wMAslkAaEHD8~TpSe7x~i4gTm4hpqt6yYLMO0SyrlsWxs7hu-1rISven3sosa7H0B8rd6eh4Ll5q8iM~RUgqibeDz6TAkHUCqIroE-8RWZY8TUPYfBOrgEHVbHZ-ReSFVCz~rkAQ9wb4m7AEBZdvcdb1i3i9PBBy1sQEzkNEDXoPH5Ru~AiE-2O~S5JY4RnrJQhxmrBc2a7TGnjUieu4CnWvnLn8gdViiG2gfwLcnSLP7KyJ1hPIfsS5wlfv7ZnBxBKPITBkphBHfdou9QWV4tg5f4iFbrU-yUStgNQhw3gjf7rQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagram constructed from line emission ratios measured in three distinct regions: the lens (A), the lensed source (B and C), and the possible merger (S). This diagram clearly shows that the origin of the ionization is different for the three objects. Purple and red solid lines correspond to the two criteria commonly used to separate star-forming (SF) from AGN-dominated galaxies from Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001) and Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003), respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446119/sty1448fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446119\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=x1RyRKkVM4Tw1aZiD6dCOLowte1CQTxVFVApws5CP8Va8ztUO8f2DD-8t4fS74ZwobK-qx1v6~96NGEbaSIfy6MB-J455w76LVF5SabCrQHTbESWxbwpNFBHTuZVl1nUcqsdhlJUcUBV0w6Qzc9j6emtm9TySOs~WjFoRSA8OTrYl7teJZ~FpDOIWviqm-YhP6w7tagAWyHMXbQ0vtv6~i9YoyXOaFIqJlW-bFI4SHxXxRLTKPYezz9CX6X-H42gz8pzdDGrdr-2~l5eOFKHek10EFDyfTByVXCrcYh~5ilks9vmq6Ed-e2Jv1CTfhhL8rMZV~YtWk3jnsZo6LTivQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446119&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">BPT</a> diagram constructed from line emission ratios measured in three distinct regions: the lens (A), the lensed source (B and C), and the possible merger (S). This diagram clearly shows that the origin of the ionization is different for the three objects. Purple and red solid lines correspond to the two criteria commonly used to separate star-forming (SF) from AGN-dominated galaxies from Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=FmHO9Jpb~BQLQ0i67FeZph1nFsVXDoFGATj900wMAslkAaEHD8~TpSe7x~i4gTm4hpqt6yYLMO0SyrlsWxs7hu-1rISven3sosa7H0B8rd6eh4Ll5q8iM~RUgqibeDz6TAkHUCqIroE-8RWZY8TUPYfBOrgEHVbHZ-ReSFVCz~rkAQ9wb4m7AEBZdvcdb1i3i9PBBy1sQEzkNEDXoPH5Ru~AiE-2O~S5JY4RnrJQhxmrBc2a7TGnjUieu4CnWvnLn8gdViiG2gfwLcnSLP7KyJ1hPIfsS5wlfv7ZnBxBKPITBkphBHfdou9QWV4tg5f4iFbrU-yUStgNQhw3gjf7rQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagram constructed from line emission ratios measured in three distinct regions: the lens (A), the lensed source (B and C), and the possible merger (S). This diagram clearly shows that the origin of the ionization is different for the three objects. Purple and red solid lines correspond to the two criteria commonly used to separate star-forming (SF) from AGN-dominated galaxies from Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001) and Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003), respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446119/sty1448fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446119\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=x1RyRKkVM4Tw1aZiD6dCOLowte1CQTxVFVApws5CP8Va8ztUO8f2DD-8t4fS74ZwobK-qx1v6~96NGEbaSIfy6MB-J455w76LVF5SabCrQHTbESWxbwpNFBHTuZVl1nUcqsdhlJUcUBV0w6Qzc9j6emtm9TySOs~WjFoRSA8OTrYl7teJZ~FpDOIWviqm-YhP6w7tagAWyHMXbQ0vtv6~i9YoyXOaFIqJlW-bFI4SHxXxRLTKPYezz9CX6X-H42gz8pzdDGrdr-2~l5eOFKHek10EFDyfTByVXCrcYh~5ilks9vmq6Ed-e2Jv1CTfhhL8rMZV~YtWk3jnsZo6LTivQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446119&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">BPT</a> diagram constructed from line emission ratios measured in three distinct regions: the lens (A), the lensed source (B and C), and the possible merger (S). This diagram clearly shows that the origin of the ionization is different for the three objects. Purple and red solid lines correspond to the two criteria commonly used to separate star-forming (SF) from AGN-dominated galaxies from Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), respectively.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the other hand, the lensed source object shows strong H\u00a0\u03b1 emission indicating recent star-formation. In the central panel of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> we show the H\u00a0\u03b1 2D emission line map, where the two images and a ring structure can clearly be seen. We note that the region within the images of the source appear clean of emission from the lens, confirming that the SSP approach works better in the lens core region. Similarly, the origin of the ionization as star-forming activity is confirmed by the location of the flux ratios in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">BPT</a> diagram (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">By determining the central wavelength of the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source in each individual spaxel, we can reconstruct the velocity field of the two images. In the right-hand panel of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show how the projected rotational velocity along the line-of-sight is in the opposite direction in each of the images. We found velocities in the range <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> \u2208 [\u221250, 50]\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118446122 id=\"118446122\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Possible merger remnant</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Another interesting result from our SSP fitting that is also evident in the left-hand panel of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, is the presence of a residual shell-like structure on the eastern side of the lens (labeled as <em>S</em> hereafter). From inspection of the original cube, this structure is clearly at the same redshift of the lens, although it presents emission lines from ionized gas. The integrated spectra of the lens model and that corresponding to the source encircled by the dotted blue region area represented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, are shown in black in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. They both have red stellar continua characteristic of old stellar populations with faint gas emission lines lying on top. The stellar continuum is noisier than the lens core but we still get a meaningful SSP fit from STARLIGHT that is shown in red. The two inner panels zoom-in to the wavelengths around H\u00a0\u03b2 and H\u00a0\u03b1. In blue, we show the difference between the observation and the SSP fit, where emission lines can clearly be identified. On the right-hand side, the reconstructed star formation history is presented, which shows that 96.25\u2009per\u2009cent and 99\u2009per\u2009cent of the SSP models needed for the best fit of the lens and the merger, respectively, correspond to populations of ages older than 3\u00a0Gyr (\u223c9.5 dex). Stellar parameters from the SSP synthesis such as the average stellar age, metallicity, stellar extinction, and stellar mass, as well as properties estimated from the gas such as the gas extinction, oxygen abundance, and ongoing star formation rate are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446124\" scrollto-destination=\"118446124\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=tLj9HdthuoA60FimWAx1LSnq420BuNeVo4s6ETrZUTCt9Y8jcZpXRm9zQl3Qkyi2seLaTgo~ltMcBP-wmL-iYP1ZVV1o1G5qRcu1q1hLI4zMGY5Bo~ed2JGlbdTsqCaHgnTFcZBMhFtQX5t50cY5yIVgUXMjpYsnUzbNbblGFLNyZeouM3W9n3bVFf8jPw5JWeGIslaVOedqGhqjRnwRtGaox1d3qC0F8JqH3dK2yhUkS7Vv6BGGKnDXWua~w9iIWb-6xtmFjwhwe7Oo~dk7UJibtTgV99U-p9B96~fklvwzhuvni8ffZ0Tu1liV4QxpNghlHtXbEwy8s-bhRPin~g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed spectrum and STARLIGHT SSP best fit of the lens galaxy (top panel) and the possible merger (bottom panel). Shaded areas are masked out in the fit as they correspond to the location of strong emission lines. On the right-hand side of each panel, the corresponding star formation history is shown with some summary parameters.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446124/sty1448fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446124\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=21jOc8VbhQMkjSCSHa5FbDhlzIt6~DqojOGBMFqEOSQPZX-A4pcziYyjV0u5oEIj0CNMbNzRU0TLjQ4q1N9QFXl7Nij0XnsYQX5TxvsxU2olXOs3aBezQGsY2xvhWAX4VoZ53zjXUV5pWL19KhnXlwlU3mbQMMADjHcP9BcNpLO-89oYjMbFhkAv9W5HS1Manf0oyraGyYm-fX37ciOGWLTVDkomw6aMeslV41CTyTSH-RglpUjeYrWTX6egX2uADhk8Kk8e4LaZUt9hQB8jXuimBTLwDUI0FYomgxASQpgHa3hhxDqAYdJJfGdOQe0lNI5nu9Oh63Fmik49hhZj4A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446124&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed spectrum and STARLIGHT SSP best fit of the lens galaxy (top panel) and the possible merger (bottom panel). (82.88)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>[S\u2009ii]\u2009\u03bb6717\u00a0</td><td>182.16 (28.52)\u00a0</td><td>781.52 (97.46)\u00a0</td><td>472.91 (50.56)\u00a0</td><td>117.79 (29.73)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>[S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u2009\u03bb6731\u00a0</td><td>116.31 (18.21)\u00a0</td><td>713.79 (80.35)\u00a0</td><td>445.37 (53.56)\u00a0</td><td>81.26 (20.51)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_V^{\\rm gas}$|</span> [mag]\u00a0</td><td>0.00 (0.02)\u00a0</td><td>1.07 (0.03)\u00a0</td><td>1.17 (0.04)\u00a0</td><td>0.47 (0.03)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>12+log<sub>10</sub> (O/H) [dex]\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>8.39 (0.09)\u00a0</td><td>8.39 (0.04)\u00a0</td><td>0.47 (0.03)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>12+log<sub>10</sub> (O/H) [dex]\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>8.39 (0.09)\u00a0</td><td>8.39 (0.10)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>log<sub>10</sub> (SFR [M<sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>]) [mag]\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0</td><td>0.27\u00a0</td><td>0.02\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&lt;log<sub>10</sub> (t<sub>*</sub> [yr])&gt; [dex]\u00a0</td><td>9.92 (0.74)\u00a0</td><td>7.31 (0.74)\u00a0</td><td>7.04 (0.66)\u00a0</td><td>10.07 (0.18)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>&lt;log<sub>10</sub> Z<sub>*</sub>&gt; [dex]\u00a0</td><td>0.022 (0.016)\u00a0</td><td>0.017 (0.013)\u00a0</td><td>0.012 (0.014)\u00a0</td><td>0.016 (0.014)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118446125\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presence of ionized gas in early-type galaxies is known to be more frequent than what was considered in recent times (e.g. Sarzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Papaderos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Singh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The source of the ionization is generally a mix between different physical processes, including four major sources: (i) nuclear activity (i.e. AGN), that have a characteristic ionization with strong [N\u2009ii]/H\u03b1 and [O\u2009iii]/H\u00a0\u03b2 ratios (e.g. Gomes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>); (ii) outflows by sometimes undiscovered central AGNs (e.g. Kehrig et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Cheung et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); (iii) ionization by young stars, remnants of a dimming disk or a consequence of a rejuvenation by the capture of a gas rich satellite galaxy (e.g. Gomes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>); and, in most of the cases, (iv) diffuse ionization by post-AGB stars (Binette et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Stasi\u0144ska et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Sarzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Papaderos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Singh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Belfiore, Maiolino &amp; Bothwell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Gomes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). Although the nature of the ionization is more or less clear, it the origin of this ionized gas that is still unclear. Although there are elliptical galaxies without trace of either ionized or cold gas, many of them show both phases of the gas (S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Thus, maybe this gas represents the left-overs of the early evolution of these galaxies, that once were gas-rich, star-forming, and have halted their activity due to gas starvation (e.g. Bekki, Couch &amp; Shioya <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, the detected structure, named as <em>S</em>, comprises both ionized gas and stellar populations, and it presents a shell-like structure located at the south east (SE) of the lens, with a diffuse (smoother) distribution towards the centre of the galaxy. Its morphology is different from the one expected either by a direct ionization by an AGN or a centrally distributed gas, or the spiral-like structure of ionization due to young stars. Its location in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_201_1530332851668\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" data-open=\"bib1_201_1530332851668\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">BPT</a> diagram indicates that the source of the ionization is LIN Baldwin, Phillips, TerlevichR-like, either associated with post-AGBs or shocks (See Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Even more, shell-like structures are characteristic of past merging events, that disrupted the morphology of the captured galaxy and/or created resonances in the distorted disk (e.g. Garc\u00eda-Lorenzo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Altogether we consider that this structure is totally unrelated to the lensed galaxy, being the remnant of a past merging event. We consider that the lens galaxy has captured, disrupted, and integrated a less massive object, more gas-rich, and it has produced the observed structure due to dynamical processes. The gas remnant is ionized either by post-AGB stars, shocks, or a combination of both processes.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446128 id=\"118446128\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 THE BACKGROUND SOURCE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimated the position of the galaxy lens core and the centre of the two source images by fitting a 2D gaussian profile in the [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6583 and the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission map, respectively (See Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We obtained an angular distance from the lens core to the south-western (B) image of \u03c3<sub>+</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.056 arcsec (1.58\u00a0kpc), and to the north-eastern image of \u03c3<sub>\u2212</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121.013 arcsec (1.27\u00a0kpc).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To study the source, we extracted 2\u2033-diameter aperture spectra at the position of the two <em>B</em> and <em>C</em> images, in both the observed datacube and in the synthetic lens model. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we show the observed spectra of the <em>B</em> and <em>C</em> images in black lines, the lens spectrum in green, and the subtraction residual in red. On the right, the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission 2-dimensional map of both sources is shown. STARLIGHT fit results of the residual spectra are listed in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446131\" scrollto-destination=\"118446131\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=hLF4KaVEFWdRcfawDKnHZR8KWCqEHAX7f-Mk33skpj15Fc0Gvggj9Jrtaq~tq9W30c8mFQ67oQ~CY4D0hJlqqZm8~sJHAWb4zxzjASiQGEPGvsWDxzrx2oDgMw2uxmsJ-4I5dC~ptLXD~0biMiaY8siwNS2U8QGiOMBuZdXWoPcsA47kKPmqxC4uyrh0kU6tvJKlc0ViWfUS7Sue5R96Dp23TmzxTtx8Kb-60AguUEXA7dOr-~hKdBIQWF7oxor3ijfnCednGQvWa80U4VLw~Xmp4uhBacuhutpkhK-986gnarPFkGgZmPVUd0HCrT2t5aBlCKF0cqyGhaK3u9y7RA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of images I+ (source B) and I\u2212 (source C).
