On the right-hand side, the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission 2D map of both sources.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446131/sty1448fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446131\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=hNYYPtJBChXFQZqtfA9TE~QQYN-Cd5v2vtUisDoL6oTPswp~WiV8fqDJvP8n2hLsz2GxOolmOlWTwSIx7JIPXM36NPHCi2Dr1KLVmPGUNzrI16UKcPHinpjM~dMRtZgZ6G-gCqDcs3exhTFyCvEEPXO5HZLTePfa3S1QU9K2TiI9EuYz-6QKAG2ciOM5VKcskMcFpmEhDFd-OnfTsipqpn2TCMOAkmiQQyhJ8Y56AGM1Lvfn9JT2CvE5sEWvuesDSe~ARrMHTdazA7rpLpWZaK7qBjLY4UIrtJTVWcvJGkOlnBGKTElxvYgrV7JXyAJx9bYkZ~uzZfIiXgIvbkn8Qw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446131&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of images I<sub>+</sub> (source <em>B</em>) and I<sub>\u2212</sub> (source <em>C</em>). In black, we show the observed spectrum obtained from a 2-arcsec diameter aperture, in green the model of the lens extracted from an aperture of the same size in the synthetic model datacube, and in red the residual. On the right-hand side, the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission 2D map of both sources.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Light from both images suffer different amounts of extinction while traveling through different sides of the lens. A larger amount of extinction is reflected in a higher observed <em>H</em>\u00a0\u03b1/<em>H</em>\u03b2 ratio, which once corrected increases the flux of H\u00a0\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb5007 over H\u00a0\u03b1 and [N\u2009ii] \u03bb6583, but does not affect (significantly) both [O<span class=\"small-caps\">\u2009iii</span>]/H\u00a0\u03b2 and [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/H\u00a0\u03b1 ratios. <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> measured from the Balmer decrement, H\u00a0\u03b1 over H\u00a0\u03b2 observed ratio, assuming an <em>R<sub>V</sub></em> of 3.1, is 1.07 (0.03) mag for <em>B</em> and 1.17 (0.04) mag for <em>C</em>. In addition, the stellar extinction obtained from the SSP fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A_V^*$|</span> is 0.27 for <em>B</em> and 0.02 for <em>C</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Oxygen abundance is measured in the two spectra using the O3N2 calibrator from Marino et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Interestingly, we find the same value from the spectra of two images, 8.39 dex. This is expected and confirms that the two images correspond indeed to the same source galaxy. On the other hand, the SFR estimated through the expression provided by Kennicutt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) using the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission flux, is a factor 1.75 higher for <em>B</em> than for <em>C</em>. We argue below that this different strength of the emission is due to the magnification effect, which is, in turn, different for each image.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446134 id=\"118446134\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed positions and fluxes of the multiple images are sensitive to the total lensing mass and its distribution within the lens. Since the observed images are extended, families of lens models that reproduce the observed image separations, but not the shape of the lensed features can be excluded.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extracting this information requires a detailed reconstruction of the observed source light profile by ray-tracing all of the observed image plane pixels through a lensing mass model back on the source plane to reconstruct a single self-consistent source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reconstruct the observed light profile of the arcs, we fit a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) for the lensing mass and a single elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile for the background source. We allow the Einstein radii, positions, position angle, and flattening of the lens to be free parameters and we do not fix any to the observed lens positions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The model is able to reconstruct the observed light profile, including the tail of the arc to the North West of image B. The best-fit model is shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The Einstein radius is 1.45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04 arcsec. We estimate errors from fitting with a PSF of 0.6\u2033and 0.8\u2033\u2009FWHM. The inferred lens cente of mass and the flattening and ellipticity are consistent with the observed light profile.</p>                        <a id=\"118446139\" scrollto-destination=\"118446139\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=HOO~yLVgR2wZlO2o3jxkQ9qChJ7XWXV~~3Ujf5WaD-nfwmKvW1A5gaN7a31CVVnHeZZp3YbluQ9M30ZXxPuX1KB10uH8HtdkJT9YOKF-aoP7xrtYOw5JCGNk~9unkx6~nWYjhZAzq-Vj2Ahf1QoThHQscUejz3w3pUF6hHwyWBqlAp0bzSMIShQ6RhN8o0O2TXeY3z34zLXV3D12RU~BffLgaWh14oN3~jn49Vqi3E3hp-5uxix7y3D1dI~JOH5iYE6lG7G9X0s6SIQvE0V5B6ubfGQVpFwodAoWcG7gQ6~cJIHkH3xefYDx6S6Yvb54v2sdW6f05l5CrEvhk5HZHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fit reconstruction of the lensed images assuming a SIE lens model and a single S\u00e9rsic profile for the source. Coordinates are in 0.2\u201d MUSE pixels. From left-hand to right-hand: data, model, residual. The residuals are poor because the PSF is not well known \u2013 there are no stars in the field of view.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446139/sty1448fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446139\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=kMmEPLk0mU20iqMowRPP9IGmasPvzYoV8XDRtT87t9N7B-~2P~drNgIfzf9VBQjbcXamh-aUIk08PkA4r-opwjfdiZw-urcPnj7VV5cT4ELXMRuWzQ-K50k8AgdS~vb~KZKMwcPM6tNYru0JuDi0CCP0i8gyxditgsFiOy~in-84nRnAeURXpmX433ic5Rtbb3refBgYSj5KOQEPSFXL4lSZZtGa8ohLUX4C~MWoRKEs6vdVYHem9HobN0OqiFPkNVfKrWrpUqrR4gfF3XU4nL7wqGzPok5vItbSNnG1kB-y8LTZxSws5sXGMwymlyCTVf-~q9SG3hcsRqBMEWIGwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446139&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fit reconstruction of the lensed images assuming a SIE lens model and a single S\u00e9rsic profile for the source. Coordinates are in 0.2\u201d MUSE pixels. From left-hand to right-hand: data, model, residual. The residuals are poor because the PSF is not well known \u2013 there are no stars in the field of view.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=HOO~yLVgR2wZlO2o3jxkQ9qChJ7XWXV~~3Ujf5WaD-nfwmKvW1A5gaN7a31CVVnHeZZp3YbluQ9M30ZXxPuX1KB10uH8HtdkJT9YOKF-aoP7xrtYOw5JCGNk~9unkx6~nWYjhZAzq-Vj2Ahf1QoThHQscUejz3w3pUF6hHwyWBqlAp0bzSMIShQ6RhN8o0O2TXeY3z34zLXV3D12RU~BffLgaWh14oN3~jn49Vqi3E3hp-5uxix7y3D1dI~JOH5iYE6lG7G9X0s6SIQvE0V5B6ubfGQVpFwodAoWcG7gQ6~cJIHkH3xefYDx6S6Yvb54v2sdW6f05l5CrEvhk5HZHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Best-fit reconstruction of the lensed images assuming a SIE lens model and a single S\u00e9rsic profile for the source. Coordinates are in 0.2\u201d MUSE pixels. From left-hand to right-hand: data, model, residual. The residuals are poor because the PSF is not well known \u2013 there are no stars in the field of view.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446139/sty1448fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446139\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=kMmEPLk0mU20iqMowRPP9IGmasPvzYoV8XDRtT87t9N7B-~2P~drNgIfzf9VBQjbcXamh-aUIk08PkA4r-opwjfdiZw-urcPnj7VV5cT4ELXMRuWzQ-K50k8AgdS~vb~KZKMwcPM6tNYru0JuDi0CCP0i8gyxditgsFiOy~in-84nRnAeURXpmX433ic5Rtbb3refBgYSj5KOQEPSFXL4lSZZtGa8ohLUX4C~MWoRKEs6vdVYHem9HobN0OqiFPkNVfKrWrpUqrR4gfF3XU4nL7wqGzPok5vItbSNnG1kB-y8LTZxSws5sXGMwymlyCTVf-~q9SG3hcsRqBMEWIGwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446139&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fit reconstruction of the lensed images assuming a SIE lens model and a single S\u00e9rsic profile for the source. Coordinates are in 0.2\u201d MUSE pixels. From left-hand to right-hand: data, model, residual. The residuals are poor because the PSF is not well known \u2013 there are no stars in the field of view.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed Einstein radius corresponds to a physical scale of 1.9\u00a0kpc and an enclosed lensing mass of 1.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118446141 id=\"118446141\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Dark matter fraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing the lensing and the stellar masses allows us to estimate the dark matter mass enclosed within the Einstein radius. To measure the dark matter fraction, we extracted a circular aperture spectrum from the 3D datacube of the STARLIGHT model of the lens (second approach described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>) with an angular size of the Einstein radius (1.45\u2033), and analyzed the spectrum with STARLIGHT to estimate the stellar mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The best SSP synthesis provides a star formation history with an average stellar age of 2.6\u00a0Gyr and an average metallicity of 1.1 Z<sub>\u2299</sub>, with two dominant bursts at log<sub>10</sub> (t [yr]) \u223c9.4 and 10.1 dex. We obtained log<sub>10</sub> M<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^*_{&lt;\\theta _E}$|</span> [M<sub>\u2299</sub>]\u00a0=\u00a010.946\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.131 dex, which corresponds to 82\u2009per\u2009cent\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08 \u2009per\u2009cent of the mass enclosed within the Einstein radius, and means that dark matter contributes 18\u2009per\u2009cent\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08 \u2009per\u2009cent to the total mass within the Einstein ring. This fraction is consistent with other reports in the literature for galaxies with similar stellar mass (Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118446144 id=\"118446144\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Velocity field and dispersion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">By ray-tracing through the best-fit lens model, we can reconstruct the velocity field of the source. This reconstruction is shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>: The source shows a velocity gradient r, with the rotation axis offset from the inferred semi-major axis of the source. A more detailed reconstruction of both lens and source is required to investigate if this offset is real.</p>                        <a id=\"118446146\" scrollto-destination=\"118446146\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=jX3ySAl-OYPz8naXm6NoZUqSY~xXCV8hrNumVF36vN~3YgeEQnXavNB6KvSGFFVkkNYHZ0UKl09p7Ox0j7~n53wQi~gB4zaY1D9x6IRAayhwIAgl~kgCfPxJ9DzCPgmVmSlRfKp5rIRLXNt-94T-nME23iUvf57SW~0acfRZFIaV~p227CHwHLKV~-QW1LZf8He-rwkon2svy5CBbNBZi8Z2xJ6xoa72TWHXyVb4wSOeLbcPNzvpzAf8iOTfMgLIoR0t1n-ylCAP--cIPAfRJGjojz8OR72BLMbCKn31scENNshv-9x-Htr2l9fk2JGcnKVfnodSIlOUpJFQTG8SwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Velocity reconstruction of the source from tracing the observed H\u00a0\u03b1 velocity onto the source plane using the best fit lens model. The best-fit reconstructed light profile is indicated by the black contours.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446146/sty1448fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446146\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=XEqj~68iwAWVqXdCSN0o4oeEOoliPrZq27XK631Rb7x5jKRkNxejre794Vk~bh53W~SL-GihAWtn4rVKwXKScr2FGgeGjQazChJBlHgxMMrL2teCE~WKuHklpSa1U7kCKrcQ7nwiYuK~Xs1XDe-YfuaIjpaD64Fdms1fOU4S90ebJzQZDbQn~~y6RmgwQhyw1dm4EfugD8-cpa4ahB4SAodF6rKrATlEminbaErY~ILZfJ-CbbQYFHevB8f1CJfUqPg1jj6dKLQtsfbdil-iM-y4ubJYjF1LRgPOr8X0MCyjd~ttSCfr8urJYpD2bqLkcRL3bJtffRXcswSTQVZPrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446146&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Velocity reconstruction of the source from tracing the observed H\u00a0\u03b1 velocity onto the source plane using the best fit lens model. The best-fit reconstructed light profile is indicated by the black contours.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=jX3ySAl-OYPz8naXm6NoZUqSY~xXCV8hrNumVF36vN~3YgeEQnXavNB6KvSGFFVkkNYHZ0UKl09p7Ox0j7~n53wQi~gB4zaY1D9x6IRAayhwIAgl~kgCfPxJ9DzCPgmVmSlRfKp5rIRLXNt-94T-nME23iUvf57SW~0acfRZFIaV~p227CHwHLKV~-QW1LZf8He-rwkon2svy5CBbNBZi8Z2xJ6xoa72TWHXyVb4wSOeLbcPNzvpzAf8iOTfMgLIoR0t1n-ylCAP--cIPAfRJGjojz8OR72BLMbCKn31scENNshv-9x-Htr2l9fk2JGcnKVfnodSIlOUpJFQTG8SwQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Velocity reconstruction of the source from tracing the observed H\u00a0\u03b1 velocity onto the source plane using the best fit lens model. The best-fit reconstructed light profile is indicated by the black contours.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446146/sty1448fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446146\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=XEqj~68iwAWVqXdCSN0o4oeEOoliPrZq27XK631Rb7x5jKRkNxejre794Vk~bh53W~SL-GihAWtn4rVKwXKScr2FGgeGjQazChJBlHgxMMrL2teCE~WKuHklpSa1U7kCKrcQ7nwiYuK~Xs1XDe-YfuaIjpaD64Fdms1fOU4S90ebJzQZDbQn~~y6RmgwQhyw1dm4EfugD8-cpa4ahB4SAodF6rKrATlEminbaErY~ILZfJ-CbbQYFHevB8f1CJfUqPg1jj6dKLQtsfbdil-iM-y4ubJYjF1LRgPOr8X0MCyjd~ttSCfr8urJYpD2bqLkcRL3bJtffRXcswSTQVZPrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446146&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Velocity reconstruction of the source from tracing the observed H\u00a0\u03b1 velocity onto the source plane using the best fit lens model. The best-fit reconstructed light profile is indicated by the black contours.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming an isothermal lens, the Einstein radius predicts a velocity dispersion of 280\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Our STARLIGHT fit for the lens model within the Einstein radius has a measured velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _v^{\\rm STAR}$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a0247\u00a0\u00b1\u00a032\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, once corrected for instrumental effects and the difference in dispersion of the bases used for the SSP synthesis. The corresponding dispersion measured in the observed spectrum within the Einstein radius is larger 298\u00a0\u00b1\u00a029\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, although in this latter case the spectrum includes emission lines and contamination from the background source that affects the SSP fitting. These results are indicative that the total density profile is approximately isothermal (Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446148 id=\"118446148\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 OTHER GALAXIES IN THE MUSE FIELD</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have used an analytical S\u00e9rsic fitting approach to remove the lens contribution from the spectra of all other galaxies in the field of view.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The way to model the spectrophotometric properties of the lens is using the two-dimensional photometric decomposition code GASP2D (M\u00e9ndez-Abreu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). It allows to fit a S\u00e9rsic model to the galaxy surface brightness distribution, thus deriving the main structural parameters of the galaxy, i.e. effective surface brightness (\u03bc<sub><em>e</em></sub>), effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>), S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>), ellipticity (\u03b5), and position angle (<em>PA</em>). GASP2D uses an iterative Levenberg\u2013Marquardt algorithm to find the solution that minimize the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. At each iteration, the galaxy model is convolved with the image Point Spread Function (PSF) before computing the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. In our case we consider the PSF to be a circular Moffat with FWHM\u00a0=\u00a00.7 arcsec and shape parameter \u03b2 = 1.95. Similarly as with the isophotal fitting, each wavelength slice of the datacube is treated as an independent galaxy image, and the best-fit S\u00e9rsic parameters are derived. The averaged S\u00e9rsic parameters over the whole wavelength range of the model are: <em>r<sub>e</sub></em><em>ff</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.8\u2033(9.30\u00a0kpc), <em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a05.2 ,\u03b5\u00a0=\u00a00.1, and <em>PA</em>=\u00a051\u00a0deg (N\u2192E). It is worth noting that a test with a S\u00e9rsic+Exponential model was also performed. However, it did not improve the single S\u00e9rsic fit and we use the latter to avoid overfitting.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once the model is subtracted from the observed datacube, we have found 15 bright sources within the FoV, besides the lens, the source, and the merger. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists their coordinates and spectroscopic redshifts of all objects detected in the FoV. To investigate the nature of their emission, we have extracted 1\u2033diameter circular aperture spectra at those positions in both the observed and the lens model datacubes and studied the residual spectra. We have been able to characterize 14 of these 15 sources, and details are given below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two sources, labeled <em>K</em> and <em>L</em> in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, show only four strong ionized gas emission lines corresponding to star-forming galaxies at redshift 0.09, as shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. In this figure, we also present 4\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04\u2033cutouts of the H\u00a0\u03b1 2D emission line map. H\u00a0\u03b1 is the strongest line in the spectrum of <em>K</em>, which also shows H\u00a0\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb4959, and [O<span class=\"small-caps\">\u2009iii]</span> \u03bb5007. Galaxy <em>L</em> has the same four lines but in this case [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb5007 is stronger than H\u00a0\u03b1. In the blue end of the spectrum, there are indications of H\u00a0\u03b3 in both spectra, but only the red wing is visible. [N\u2009ii] \u03bb\u03bb6548,6583 doublet is not present in any of the two galaxies, which avoids estimating oxygen abundance through typical empirical calibrations. However, in both spectra [O\u2009iii] \u03bb5007 is stronger than H\u00a0\u03b2 indicating low-metallicity. No STARLIGHT fit was performed due to the faint stellar continuum, but fluxes of all prominent emission lines are reported in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446153\" scrollto-destination=\"118446153\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;-fIJubQrFM6eLHRPQRzy7KrraNEpm-A9YpbBtEfhdbE4uX0rw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of background galaxies K and L both at $z$=\u00a00.09. (4.67)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>P\u00a0</td><td>47.30 (9.43)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>9.79 (2.38)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>16.58 (3.66)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Q\u00a0</td><td>59.05 (12.89)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>20.78 (4.70)\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td><td>\u2212\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118446154\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further than <em>K</em> and <em>L</em>, we find the lensed source galaxy at z\u00a0=\u00a00.1915, and following that we detected seven different sources at redshifts around 0.45. They are all marked in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> with yellow circles, and labeled with letters <em>D</em> to <em>J</em>. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> we present all their spectra extracted from a 1 arcsec diameter aperture, together with 4\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04\u2033cutouts of the S/N of the spectra as measured in the observed-frame 50\u2009\u00c5 window centred at 6000\u2009\u00c5. Five objects had a bright red continuum and no emission lines representative of passivegalaxies dominated by old stellar populations. We fit these spectra with STARLIGHT and provide their properties in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. Objects <em>F</em> and <em>H</em> have significantly fainter continua and present a few strong emission lines. For this reason, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> we show the 2D [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb5007 map instead of a S/N 4\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04\u2033cutout. In both galaxies, the spectrum does not cover the wavelength region corresponding to H\u03b1 in the rest-frame, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb5007 is the strongest emission line. Again, this line is stronger than H\u03b2 indicating metal-poor nature.</p>                        <a id=\"118446156\" scrollto-destination=\"118446156\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=iTdIHbqteTi9Uu8SCW~zJskI3hOrp-lPkF6RtvWHHoiKnFkLAUIAJSBoMsm1X~c0upiXIrEOK7nFcmMNlAZIgHn1gymzdDvJEXbUPHqmG~gQV6toeJnjGUAff2zzyehro2kD82F3TFEraL02kOANNsAOD7MZakKPI8z40XHZc09w2a9qd3Y~zfO4VTVkMqqYKzAPDGxB68LDzr~dkvNuinWPnmdCbJS5C0tNKUuIiaPciosL2~JmnyPFbGtdyREofA0CYmqoVumegovpz~H~tE3qpbCgj07dTNRIL10F-iWs-50oAMoWX0mRaDmccq41F3r1aoQWk1p6PFs48zxy7g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of background galaxies D to J, all at redshifts $z$\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.45. extracted in the observed cube.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118446157\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The next set of galaxies, <em>M, N</em>, and <em>O</em> in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, are at redshift \u223c0.59. All their spectra, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, are compatible to passive red galaxies at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.59. We were able to fit STARLIGHT to the three spectra, and their properties are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446159\" scrollto-destination=\"118446159\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig alt=\"Similar to Fig.\u00a09 for galaxies M, N, and O detected at redshifts $z$\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.59.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446159/sty1448fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446159\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=sNBP-xb6gHbKptStNSdXjCbOjI2pbLL9JpjyScPPxbGRd45-pKC-E2m3R9LAuxzOuSgbuX2mfzkt91ZDVLgeWxSrayO7FMkVVhWsXwHGtbgf0m8vrvVXI7RCd1YervTGY3qJwuJ~QNGeWSvWYntKU5lm4lDhe0DjPIcyDz7iySeVsX4DgJj9hjmKbduwFAFlcu6vQez-4lQ6heKZ7xvLxTubEjAxi7t9TPYv2zxj5TIAJESlaudrTOiI3KGe2tGJAhyl-j6xJNWOudLJFiMV5l1BHUWOPQ8u9tZ8B30xpHlxAqZkHIzYxlCe7pCTh3E06rgUDe8rFxalw6bemgR77A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446159&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similar to Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> for galaxies <em>M, N</em>, and <em>O</em> detected at redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.59.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> we present the spectra and cutouts of the other three galaxies found in the FoV. The <em>S</em>/<em>N</em>of these spectra are too low for fitting SSP with STARLIGHT, but we are able to determine the redshift from their emission lines in two cases: object <em>P</em> is at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>=\u00a00.6286 according to the [O\u2009ii] \u03bb\u03bb3727,29 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb5007 lines, and object <em>Q</em> is at 0.9031 from [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb\u03bb3727,29 and H\u03b2 lines. We have not been able to find good matches for object <em>R</em>, although we are convinced of the detection from its red continuum and the blob in the S/N map. New, deeper spectroscopic observation is needed to provide further information for object <em>R</em>.</p>                        <a id=\"118446161\" scrollto-destination=\"118446161\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" <em>Q</em> detected at redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.62 and 0.90, respectively, and object <em>R</em> at unknown redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=CCOuWlgXS3Vob4lABqULiXiqvG9qWQepL0pKMwrfCiX5xlQRbPRamnUzKFpgYYs4x~SAb3RSPw~ifnMUCp3jIxKKUthS0S0q2SsMvZGMVZRCaajZWLQyc5qmOZjRXuzYn4-E8jjf6nY30CTAc2YCQZl3qSa4OEkwEDE2RLuFcEpebqLYe6ns7pUFjzCpOj6QN6Czb1Ujzgz~18UBxTXSNrWWeld31XCm~4wbwSdBfw5maKOhE1w4xTUQqSu-ctqcr91dCrcABwsobr7Qz7CmgbutRbKgRUD4eiYV0-Gs3x9V0aos8JpREtw1CmQ6VWRhjl2H2Gn9-H1DXmrr~xsL5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446161/sty1448fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446161\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=H5~rU0UcCAmb8cyVF6urrZumfnFsRYys3dFcJ9UOJ3GSdUyFB1jh1GyMbfO3jP5HDah3bzJYMDLjV157xMpNCs4bWfG7KcTKV2VPc4x4PnI0VK3CkRCtNGgcuR19E9-9axleO0GCfb1NRJZLAdOTUDUzkrDFToyiWCob1DP922EBdu1GnE0NCPQC7dA3mpouoG0sPkBZ2J9cZiYvp75B0l~Q3WW4mnv4zZQqxJJaH-8VNsqmlw3F-krv8p2W1w-R2uYm8VyS5K51D1cUY8VRTL1~mmzNZA1ZgnIWn7d6Czlvanwo5ExaBI0t0nLnwIecofKNBe5sUq7BLRwT6FQxFg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446161&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similar to Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> for galaxies <em>P</em> and <em>Q</em> detected at redshifts <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.62 and 0.90, respectively, and object <em>R</em> at unknown redshift.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446162 id=\"118446162\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We reported the discovery of a strong lensed galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>=\u00a00.1915 by the lens 2MASX J04035024\u20130239275 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00.0661 in IFS observations from MUSE at the 8.2m VLT of Cerro Paranal.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two images from the source are identified and, after a careful analysis, confirmed as lensed images coming from the same source. We modelled the lens with a SIE mass profile and a S\u00e9rsic background source, finding an Einstein radius of 1.45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04 \u2033(1.9\u00a0kpc), consistent with an isothermal density profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Independent of our discovery, a recent archival search of public MUSE data by Collier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) also identified this galaxy as a strong gravitational lens. While they predict the dark matter fraction from cosmological hydrodynamical simulations, we derive our stellar mass estimate from the SSP synthesis with STARLIGHT to the MUSE data integrated within the Einstein radius. In both cases, we find a consistent fraction of dark matter within the Einstein radius (\u223c18 \u2009per\u2009cent). However, the main difference between both works is the approach used to estimate the average age of the stellar populations in the lens galaxy. This may have significant consequences when using such parameters to infer the initial mass function (IMF) excess parameter (alpha). Indeed, Collier et\u00a0al. claim a lightweight IMF rather than a standard Salpeter value for the lens galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Collier et\u00a0al. estimate a reference mass-to-light ratio, (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>)<sub>ref</sub>, for the IMF excess parameter by fitting a single-burst model to a spectrum extracted with an aperture of the Einstein radius. Following this approach, they are able to recover the dominant population which has a stellar age of 12\u00a0Gyr and a metallicity 1.5 Z<sub>\u2299</sub>. Just considering this single population, they are making the strong/uncertain assumptions that: (1) all stars in the galaxy have the same age, metallicity, and were created at the same time; (2) the <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> is constant through the extension of the Einstein radius; and (3) the IMF is constant through the same extension. All these assumptions are at odds with current understanding of galaxy formation and evolution from spatially resolved analyses of SPs where each population has its own specific M/L. In addition, these assumptions are clearly not in agreement with the current view of elliptical galaxies (e.g. see fig.\u00a05 in S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, and fig.\u00a08 in Gonz\u00e1lez Delgado et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A more detailed approach would consist on performing SSP synthesis to infer the full star formation history. The analysis with STARLIGHT on the spectrum of an aperture of the Einstein radius (1.45\u2033) provides an average age of 2.6\u00a0Gyr and metallicity around solar (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>). We recover SPs of old ages (&gt;10 dex) but a whole range of younger populations, in particular two peaks at 2.8 and 12.5\u00a0Gyr (9.4 and 10.1 dex). As a comparison, fig.\u00a08 in Gallazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) shows the distribution of age and metallicity as a function of stellar mass for high signal-to-noise SDSS galaxies. For the stellar mass of the lens galaxy, 10.94 dex, our estimates of age and metallicity are within 1 sigma of the SDSS distribution, while those by Collier et\u00a0al. are outliers. In addition, Portinari, Sommer-Larsen &amp; Tantalo (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) in their fig.\u00a02 show that for stellar ages of 12\u00a0Gyr the (M/L)<sub>ref</sub> is around a factor 2 larger than for populations of \u223c3\u00a0Gyr ages. Therefore, our extracted values would provide a much lower (M/L)<sub>ref</sub> and an \u03b1 \u22731.5 totally compatible with a Salpeter IMF.</p>                        <a id=\"118446168\" scrollto-destination=\"118446168\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=ZfDHRXxYqLmouNY0t7F7UYtVtSqp68HG7WMuOgSvvKN8YS7c3eBFtCV~0wkuka5HskxDIxEb1sa39lcxEXYq7ZQP61dK6GFWjwuR~5mbXzBaeOsgHWbkn3uoGNI0DdIFl9QA1xRuuY0u9sjFNG0sqixUzqHkGAW63UAs9G7VZRfBdhT7U8~YGNpzcKAEOTzHBGlIMmv3RC-fehaavqaCxq~uldaFfVbcj24D~GGRJCub0LCDWp4~LzVr7cM60u1Mk4O4PdURwVGcN-cKhun-fyLTrH60e6Pw-4gziMPAqwVt7z~qdlRjZOHkRbvaoR9lcDbZl7rvmJpJxQNrTnU8CQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Star formation history of the spectrum extracted from the observed MUSE cube with an aperture of the Einstein radius (1.45 arcsec). Vertical brown lines on top correspond to the ages of the base SSPs used in the STARLIGHT fit. The light-weighted average age is 2.6\u00a0Gyr. We recover a small fraction of &lt;1\u00a0Gyr populations, and two clear peaks around 2.8 and 12.5\u00a0Gyr.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446168/sty1448fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446168\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=RH61piLU54FEEWuLAce1y8KporufnmHk91ts62T9AxM8k9Q9uBSz2zi4m6MPUoQp-ETIOBhT42q~Tmz1CGcZPJdnfljIs-a5z9fV13Uh8TE1kAYb4PuJhX1rkjvoLu0FfhOYGlLyZxtDM9NrPkZWRlQOyzpS-QkMVI9GxCa9eTNk57xTlXEZrij0JhL25tUzXyjHKu0hP8FsCJasldBW-DE~4zfdke7WDcKDj4Qco66uk5jbX2dbJq5FXP6hXwkexygjUnTHvDcYRAteWtlxxYQd0vjnAzay8GBW6iFqfH2rTucI2ah-G4VCvdGzl4pyKj6sgVAIXkMApvYdTzsYlA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446168&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Star formation history of the spectrum extracted from the observed MUSE cube with an aperture of the Einstein radius (1.45 arcsec). Vertical brown lines on top correspond to the ages of the base SSPs used in the STARLIGHT fit. The light-weighted average age is 2.6\u00a0Gyr. We recover a small fraction of &lt;1\u00a0Gyr populations, and two clear peaks around 2.8 and 12.5\u00a0Gyr.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=ZfDHRXxYqLmouNY0t7F7UYtVtSqp68HG7WMuOgSvvKN8YS7c3eBFtCV~0wkuka5HskxDIxEb1sa39lcxEXYq7ZQP61dK6GFWjwuR~5mbXzBaeOsgHWbkn3uoGNI0DdIFl9QA1xRuuY0u9sjFNG0sqixUzqHkGAW63UAs9G7VZRfBdhT7U8~YGNpzcKAEOTzHBGlIMmv3RC-fehaavqaCxq~uldaFfVbcj24D~GGRJCub0LCDWp4~LzVr7cM60u1Mk4O4PdURwVGcN-cKhun-fyLTrH60e6Pw-4gziMPAqwVt7z~qdlRjZOHkRbvaoR9lcDbZl7rvmJpJxQNrTnU8CQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Star formation history of the spectrum extracted from the observed MUSE cube with an aperture of the Einstein radius (1.45 arcsec). Vertical brown lines on top correspond to the ages of the base SSPs used in the STARLIGHT fit. The light-weighted average age is 2.6\u00a0Gyr. We recover a small fraction of &lt;1\u00a0Gyr populations, and two clear peaks around 2.8 and 12.5\u00a0Gyr.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446168/sty1448fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446168\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=RH61piLU54FEEWuLAce1y8KporufnmHk91ts62T9AxM8k9Q9uBSz2zi4m6MPUoQp-ETIOBhT42q~Tmz1CGcZPJdnfljIs-a5z9fV13Uh8TE1kAYb4PuJhX1rkjvoLu0FfhOYGlLyZxtDM9NrPkZWRlQOyzpS-QkMVI9GxCa9eTNk57xTlXEZrij0JhL25tUzXyjHKu0hP8FsCJasldBW-DE~4zfdke7WDcKDj4Qco66uk5jbX2dbJq5FXP6hXwkexygjUnTHvDcYRAteWtlxxYQd0vjnAzay8GBW6iFqfH2rTucI2ah-G4VCvdGzl4pyKj6sgVAIXkMApvYdTzsYlA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446168&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Star formation history of the spectrum extracted from the observed MUSE cube with an aperture of the Einstein radius (1.45 arcsec). Vertical brown lines on top correspond to the ages of the base SSPs used in the STARLIGHT fit. The light-weighted average age is 2.6\u00a0Gyr. We recover a small fraction of &lt;1\u00a0Gyr populations, and two clear peaks around 2.8 and 12.5\u00a0Gyr.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we note that to discriminate between different IMFs is unfeasible considering (among other reasons): (i) the spectral range covered by the current dataset, laking the blue part of the spectrum, in particular de D4000 region; (ii) our current uncertainties in the SSPs libraries, which make it difficult to measure the M/L at the precision required; (iii) not having a good way to measure the [alpha/Fe] gradient which, by itself, could mimic the observed discrepancy; and (iv) the known uncertainties in the fitting procedures. Finally, we stress that putting constraints on the IMF was not the main goal of this work, and we refer to state-of-the-art IMF derivations, such as those from Mart\u00edn-Navarro et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) or by the Atlas3D group (Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), to outline the complexity of the matter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fifteen other galaxies have been detected in the 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> FoV, in addition to the identification of a possible merger with the lensing galaxy. None of these background sources are strongly lensed. We provided spectroscopic redshifts and stellar and ionized gas properties for 14 of these background galaxies. Object <em>R</em> shows a red continuum, but we were unable to get reliable constrains on its redshift. Deeper observations are needed for such constrains.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we have been able to put constraints on the dark matter content within the Einstein radius of a nearby elliptical galaxy acting as a lens for a background galaxy, and present an analysis in great detail. Looking to the future, the advent of large surveys such as the LSST will be able to discover a significant number of new strong-lensed systems, and we demonstrated how wide-field Integral field spectroscopy offers an excellent approach to study them and to precisely model its effects.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446172 id=\"118446172\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We are greatly thankful to Michael Wood-Vasey, Rachel Mandelbaum, Santiago Gonz\u00e1lez-Gait\u00e1n, Lindsay Oldham, Andrew Zentner, and Jeff Newman, for very valuable input on the early stages of this project. L.G. was supported in part by the US National Science Foundation under Grant AST-1311862. TEC is funded by a Dennis Sciama Fellowship from the University of Portsmouth. Based on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under program 98.D-0115(A). Llenya d\u2019alzina, vi de sarment, oli d\u2019oliva, pa de forment.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446174 id=\"118446174\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We note that this lens has also been independently discovered by Collier, Smith &amp; Lucey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), using the same MUSE data from our ESO programme 098.D-0115(A); PI: Galbany.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">This wavelength was selected because it corresponds to the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of galaxies <em>L</em> and <em>K</em>. They only show a few bright emission lines on top of a very faint and noisy continuum (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), and otherwise they would not be visible in the image.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446177 id=\"118446177\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. W.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bolton</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. J.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Moustakas</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. class=\"widget widget-ArticleTopInfo widget-instance-OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    Serendipitous discovery of a strong-lensed galaxy in integral field spectroscopy from MUSE\r\n<i class='' title='' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Llu\u00eds Galbany</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Llu\u00eds Galbany\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-default\"><!----></a></span>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">PITT PACC, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-author-correspondence\">\r\n $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f479%2f1%2f262%2f5032805\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446090 id=\"118446090\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 is a bright red elliptical galaxy at redshift 0.0661 that presents two extended sources at 2\u2033 to the north-east and 1\u2033 to the south-west. The sizes and surface brightnesses of the two blue sources are consistent with a gravitationally-lensed background galaxy. In this paper, we present Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) observations of this galaxy from the All-weather MUse Supernova Integral-field Nearby Galaxies (AMUSING) survey, and report the discovery of a background lensed galaxy at redshift 0.1915, together with other 15 background galaxies at redshifts ranging from 0.09 to 0.9, that are not multiply imaged. We have extracted aperture spectra of the lens and all the sources and fit the stellar continuum with STARLIGHT to estimate their stellar and emission line properties. A trace of past merger and active nucleus activity is found in the lensing galaxy, while the background lensed galaxy is found to be star-forming. Modelling the lensing potential with a singular isothermal ellipsoid, we find an Einstein radius of 1<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>04, which corresponds to 1.9\u00a0kpc at the redshift of the lens and it is much smaller than its effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09\u2033). Comparing the Einstein mass and the STARLIGHT stellar mass within the same aperture yields a dark matter fraction of 18 per\u2009cent\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08 \u2009per\u2009cent within the Einstein radius. The advent of large surveys such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) will discover a number of strong-lensed systems, and here we demonstrate how wide-field integral field spectroscopy offers an excellent approach to study them and to precisely model lensing effects.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: spectroscopic&quot;\">techniques: spectroscopic</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: general&quot;\">galaxies: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446092 id=\"118446092\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">General relativity predicts that light from distant galaxies is deflected by foreground massive objects, such as more nearby galaxies or clusters. In cases where the source and deflector are sufficiently well aligned, multiple images of the source will form around the lensing foreground object (Einstein <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1915</a>; Zwicky <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1937</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing produces highly magnified images that allow the study of fainter and smaller galaxies than would otherwise be possible with current instrumentation (Narayan &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). Also, it provides the most precise and accurate method to determine the masses of galaxies in a model-free fashion being independent of assumptions such as the initial mass function (IMF) or galaxy dynamics (Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In addition, the comparison between the inferred total mass distribution in strong lenses to their observed brightness profile provides valuable information about the galaxy dark matter content and distribution (Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Strong lensing systems can also place constraints on cosmological parameters (Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Low redshift lenses are particularly interesting systems as their Einstein radii form at a much smaller physical scale than for higher redshift lenses. This enables studies of the central matter distribution in these lenses. Their much lower distances also allow more detailed follow-up of the lens kinematics and stellar populations. Recent studies have combined these approaches to place tight constraints on the IMF (Smith, Lucey &amp; Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the validity of General relativity (Collett 2018a), and the Hubble constant (Collett et al 2018b, in prep). Unfortunately, despite the utility of low redshift strong lenses only a handful are known (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) due to the rarity of massive galaxies and the small volume at very low redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While some lensed systems have been discovered serendipitously by visually checking images of the lens, there have been several dedicated attempts to identify strong gravitational lensed objects around massive galaxies. Previous search strategies typically used both photometric or spectroscopic methods. Photometric methods include searching for arc morphologies (e.g. Blakeslee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), or outliers in colour diagrams (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), given that foreground and background objects have different colours. The majority of these methods are based on a priori knowledge of galaxy properties, and visual inspection is usually required. Most recently, new automatic methods based on deep learning are flowering (Lanusse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Alternatively, spectroscopic methods that are based on detecting rogue emission (or absorption) lines in galaxy spectra (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) have been employed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) reported the discovery of a lensed galaxy in integral field spectroscopy (IFS) observations of SDSS J170124.01+372258.0 from the MaNGA survey (Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).This methodology has been greatly extended by Talbot et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) to discover 38 lenses from MaNGA, with lens redshifts spanning 0.02 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>l</em></sub> &lt; 0.13. Despite the clear detection of weak emission lines in the datacube corresponding to a star-forming background galaxy at different redshift than the lens, the low spatial resolution of MaNGA data does not yet allow for a detailed understanding of the observed lensing mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We here report the discovery of strong gravitational lensing by the galaxy 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> in IFS obtained with the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), an IFU instrument with high resolutions in both spectral (<em>R</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03000) and spatial (0.2\u2033/spaxel) dimensions, which permits a detailed reconstruction of the source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the observations. Then, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we describe the lens model and the residual datacube after subtraction. In Section<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, the lensed source. In Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we present a simple model of the observed image configuration and the lensing mass. In Section<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>, we summarize and list our conclusions. Throughout this work, we use the best-fit cosmological parameters of Planck Collaboration et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118446100 id=\"118446100\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 is a bright red elliptical galaxy at R.A.\u00a0=\u00a004<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>26, Dec\u00a0=\u00a0\u221202\u00b039\u203227<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>64 with a radial velocity <em>cz</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a019,952\u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), corresponding to an angular scale of 1.256\u00a0kpc arcsec<sup>\u22121</sup>. The type Ia supernova LSQ13cwp exploded 9.6\u2033N and 6.1\u2033E from the galaxy core and was discovered on November 8th 2013 (Walker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For this reason, 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 was included in the sample of supernova host galaxies of the All-weather MUse Supernova Integral-field Nearby Galaxies (AMUSING; Galbany et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) survey. AMUSING is an ongoing project aimed at studying the environments of supernovae (SNe) by means of the analysis of a large number of nearby SN host galaxies (redshifts typically between 0.005 and 0.1). The AMUSING sample currently comprises more than 300 galaxies observed in the last six semesters (P95\u2013P100). It also comprises a wide variety of galaxy types with the common characteristics of having hosted a known SN.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 was observed using the integral-field spectrograph MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) at the ESO Very Large Telescope (VLT) UT4 of the Cerro Paranal Observatory during a clear night on 2016 November 7. In the Wide-Field Mode, MUSE covers a continuous sky region of 1\u2032\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u2032 with a small spaxel size of 0.2\u2033\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.2\u2033, which limits the spatial resolution of the data to the atmospheric seeing during the observation (\u223c0.7\u2033). MUSE observations cover the wavelength range spanning from 4750\u2009\u00c5\u00a0to 9300\u2009\u00c5, with a spectral sampling of 1.25\u2009\u00c5 and a resolving power <em>R</em> increasing from 1800 in the blue edge to 3600 in the red edge of the spectrum. With its excellent total throughput, MUSE offers an unprecedented combination of sensitivity, spatial resolution, and field of view (FoV).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained four dithered (by a few arcsec) exposures of 700s integration each, totaling 2800s on source, that resulted in a combined datacube with more than 105,000 individual spectra. There are no stars in the field of our MUSE observations, but we checked the image quality of the slow-guiding system (SGS) that uses metrology fields around the MUSE field of view (FoV) to provide a secondary telescope guiding. Three stars were detected in those fields with an average full-width half-maximum (FWHM) of 0.676\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.040 arcsec. We therefore assume throughtout the paper the point spread function (PSF) is a circular Gaussian with an FWHM of 0.7\u2033, which corresponds to a physical resolution of 880\u00a0pc at the redshift of the lens, and it is consistent with the reported Differential imaging motion motor (DIMM) seeing. Data reduction was performed following prescriptions reported in Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) and Kr\u00fchler et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and the reader is referred to those papers for details.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">IFS can be thought as a sequence of two-dimensional (2D) very narrow-band imaging of the Field of view (FoV) covered by the instrument. In the case of MUSE, this translates into 1.25\u2009\u00c5-wide 3,681 images. Each of these images correspond to a different rest-frame wavelength for objects at different redshifts in the FoV.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection of the 2MASX J04035024-0239275 datacube revealed a bright detached source located a few spaxels South-West of the core of the main galaxy. A spectrum extracted with a small aperture at the position of the source resembled that of a typical star-forming galaxy at a higher redshift than the main galaxy (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u223c\u00a00.19). Examining the wavelength slice (narrow-band image) of the datacube corresponding to the H\u03b1 emission of this source (7820\u2009\u00c5), we discovered another source at the North-Eastern side of the 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 core (see inset of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The spectrum of this 2nd source was found to be very similar to the S-E object, and the estimated redshifts were consistent. Further inspection of the datacube revealed up to 15 other galaxies present in the FoV. Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows a synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image from the datacube centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5 in the observer frame,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> where all objects detected are marked with circles of different colours grouped by their corresponding measured redshifts. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists coordinates and spectroscopic redshifts of all objects detected in the FoV. The inner panel presents a zoom-in of the 2MASX J04035024\u22120239275 core, from a synthetic narrow-band image centred at 7820\u2009\u00c5, where it can be clearly seen the core (labeled as <em>A</em> throughout the paper) and the two S-W (labeled as <em>B</em>) and N-E (labeled as <em>C</em>) bright blobs.</p>                        <a id=\"118446106\" scrollto-destination=\"118446106\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=fyfthPRzVrM5PqhdM~Pe57Ojn6UsMrGApKAfuiVNY7FlVS0HX4sr~Qi0ARuI9LAH-a4PFElYYS51DEZIJI~CyQ7Vrf8Pjf-lTaxtgtuI64ZgPH8aLJcikXn2N7eCVsHsS-wjLwVSVkeaPWIldesSAUGBMY115qjRSoypmmTuvnqUpmAPcDh6VrYLUIa34ot1zl4kR~8Ybj1c2gF6W5k6a6guNJgRGXsyoZZ29fr19HhR9ahFrrpK59QJTKBKO1ANv8HuzZBxcMnWkv0uHJk-DipBLFUpPYfeN6oTceAOHpJBqRS1tqf8KVCk6vCesfDQBOgI8ieOS0epeI~nlHDiJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. We identified 16 different sources in the field of view, indicated with circles. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source ($z$\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. Supernova LSQ13cwp position is represented by a white plus sign.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118446106/sty1448fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118446106\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&Signature=PlSgyp1SI9sSHdrzwI9iDd5Zh6PzkjPTX8RZ5W5-5CSSyTCkZI4fc065ja5qzvyDNIszwZLHGjPj6nAWRTUs0mhX2mHDuMhdTuRYv0LLl3ZhptVevrF6il4yjOJKQPPYgP8iE7nMLFzxdDhnu70efkwaa-0DZSoSRenj2502jIF~K6jAEzun69Tk5HjUAVvKowL1W4LWlJw4BtlheADTGYXEr6Wyu1boD5kuVKVijQm6qjFy4bWLWXE3LKq9Ql0rV3ZKqMLuZ0JaryGqfYb3bYIFZ7KRyhOXDHgeY1AX1IY2Qw~TO3IvMlA2clCo4QNC9XFEg-In1~p9llkf5uyeMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118446106&ar=5032805&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1448fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. We identified 16 different sources in the field of view, indicated with circles. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. Supernova LSQ13cwp position is represented by a white plus sign.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1448/1/m_sty1448fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465882&amp;Signature=fyfthPRzVrM5PqhdM~Pe57Ojn6UsMrGApKAfuiVNY7FlVS0HX4sr~Qi0ARuI9LAH-a4PFElYYS51DEZIJI~CyQ7Vrf8Pjf-lTaxtgtuI64ZgPH8aLJcikXn2N7eCVsHsS-wjLwVSVkeaPWIldesSAUGBMY115qjRSoypmmTuvnqUpmAPcDh6VrYLUIa34ot1zl4kR~8Ybj1c2gF6W5k6a6guNJgRGXsyoZZ29fr19HhR9ahFrrpK59QJTKBKO1ANv8HuzZBxcMnWkv0uHJk-DipBLFUpPYfeN6oTceAOHpJBqRS1tqf8KVCk6vCesfDQBOgI8ieOS0epeI~nlHDiJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Synthetic 10\u2009\u00c5 narrow-band image (centred at 7184\u2009\u00c5) of the MUSE observation. The inset is a synthetic narrow-band image centred at the H\u00a0\u03b1 emission of the source ($z$\u00a0=\u00a00.1915) where the lens and the two images of the source can clearly be distinguished. no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4556\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>E\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>50<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>53\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203242<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>0\u00a0</td><td>0.4551\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>F\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm s}_{.}}$|</span>71\u00a0</td><td>\u221202\u00b039\u203239<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6\u00a0</td><td>0.4538\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4564\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>48<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>2\u00a0</td><td>0.4542\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>I\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>8\u00a0</td><td>0.4549\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6\u00a0</td><td>0.0946\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>L\u00a0</td><td>4<sup>h</sup>03<sup>m</sup>49<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\rm
